Actually, you could just match up genes during crossover by comparing
their=
 [in, out] connection tuples for value equality (avoiding
problems from has=
h collisions).

What is the difference between that and the historical mark=
er approach?

On Sun, May 20, 2012 at 12:11 AM, Thomas Jack <thomasjack@gma=
il.com> wrote:
> Suppose that, instead of incrementing a global counter to =
assign
> historical markings to new genes, you just use a consistent hash
>=
 function on the connection tuple of [in, out] ids. This would mean, I
> th=
ink, that you don't have to keep a per-generation list of structural
> muta=
tions, but the historical markers for matching structural
> mutations will =
always be the same, across all generations.
>
> Is there some benefit to th=
e approach described in the NEAT
> publications that I'm missing, or should=
 this work fine?
>
> One difference is that you can't differentiate between=
 disjoint and
> excess genes, and so lose one of the c1,c2 hyperparameters =
=97 is this
> important?
